posts.name: Troy Crooks
posts.cooked:
This year we are trying to tackle swerve.

Right now our robot can turn and drive, but after driving around the wheels all get disaligned. So I am trying to use a formula from swerve drive specialties github

public Mk2SwerveModuleBuilder angleEncoder(AnalogInput encoder, double offset) {

The problem is that this formula uses the andyMark MA3 Absolute Encoder, but we have the CTRE Mag Encoder.

and the encoder.getVoltage(); does not exist for the CTRE Encoder

So my question does everyone know how to get the voltage of the CTRE Mag Encoder?

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Just to confirm, this is not a ‚ÄúCANcoder‚Äù?  Assuming a ‚ÄúSRX MAG ENCODER‚Äù‚Ä¶

First, you need to know where this is hooked up ‚Äì are you using it with a Talon SRX, with a Falcon, a NEO/SPARK MAX, or something else?  If so, is it hooked up to the motor controller, or are you doing something else?  How it is hooked up (and confirming the type of encoder) can make a big difference in the answer.  You need to provide details on the sensor, the motor controller (and possibly the motor), and on the electrical connections.  But, there is no analog output from this sensor (which is OK, but will require changes on the S/W side ‚Äì there are quite a few different variations on Mk2SwerveModuleBuilder).  This may be applicable:

Using the VEX SRX Mag Encoders with Spark Max Sensors

link_counts.title: Using the VEX SRX Mag Encoders with Spark Max

posts.name: Troy Crooks
posts.cooked:
These are srx mag encoders, and we have wired them to be absolute encoders ( 3 wires signal, ground, positive).  We have tried to connect them to both PWM and Anolog input.

Is it possible to use the encoder as an analog input in order to get the voltage?

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: No. The sensor outputs a PWM signal that you need to read. The output is 1-4095us pulse depending on the position. It will not do analog.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
The typical usage is likely to be Falcon 500 with CANcoder or NEO 550/SPARK MAX with SRX MAG ENCODER (I think these are the official capitalizations; not trying to shout).  I assume you are doing the latter, but then it sounds as though you are trying to connect the encoder directly to the roboRIO.  Starting with the sensor, here are the electrical outputs (from the manual): image 527√ó511 52.4 KB

image 527√ó511 52.4 KB

image 527√ó511 52.4 KB

This pinout is actually matched to the Talon SRX, so some signals from the motor controller are broken out on the encoder but are not supplied by the encoder ‚Äì specifically, the two limit switch inputs.  So, the sensor outputs are a PWM signal and a quadrature encoder signal (A/B).  The PWM signal is absolute, while the quadrature signal is incremental.  Each of these has an advantage, but you likely need at least the absolute position information.

The link above is a discussion on connecting this sensor directly to a SPARK MAX.  A direct connection to the motor controller has some advantages, so this is probably the more common usage and requires using the data port on the controller, and configuring it to " Alternate Encoder Mode".  But this only uses the quadrature outputs (A/B) of the encoder.

So, you most likely want to use a digital input that can decode PWM on the roboRIO.  There are two ways you can go here: 1) use a DIO input and have the RIO turn this into a value; 2) use some external circuitry to filter the PWM signal into an analog one, then bring this in via an analog input to the RIO. Here is a technical article on the simple circuit typically used to do this PWM to analog conversion.

I‚Äôm not sure the RIO can currently take a PWM in through DIO ‚Äì see Reading Duty Cycle from DIO via FPGA - #3 by Peter_Johnson .  If not, then that option is probably a non-starter.

So you need to build the simple circuit shown here:

This is literally less than ten cents of parts, and not much more involved than just the wires.  I‚Äôll either try to find an existing thread here on CD or do another post showing calculation of these values later today when I have time.

link_counts.title: Reading Duty Cycle from DIO via FPGA

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
That‚Äôs called an RC Filter, and it won‚Äôt work here, at least not well. The Mag Encoder PWM runs at about 250Hz, so adding the filter onto it will reduce the effective update rate to 25Hz or less. Basically, if you want it to be somewhat accurate, it will be very, very laggy. There‚Äôs chips to convert PWM to Analog but they are fairly involved and difficult to use. Wouldn‚Äôt recommend it.

There is a way to use the Counter class to read a pulse width duty cycle. I don‚Äôt remember how exactly to do it but the code definitely exists.

EDIT: Found it: Counters ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation Pulse-length mode.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Here is another article, with some more technical detail.

Here are the PWM signal specifications for the sensor: image 710√ó167 33.8 KB

image 710√ó167 33.8 KB

image 710√ó167 33.8 KB

So, ‚Äúùëì PWM ‚Äù is 244Hz (nominally, the specification gives a range).  (This translates into a period of 4098Œºs, or around 4ms.)  V L is ~0.0V and V H is ~3.3V.  The minimum pulse width is just a little above 0%, and the maximum pulse width in just a little below 100% (there needs to always be a periodic pulse, which isn‚Äôt there for a waveform that spends all time either low or high).  Also, the maximum output current is limited to 2mA.

There‚Äôs a handy design tool online here .  The tool takes a ‚ÄúDuty Step‚Äù, from 0% to X%.  In this application, mechanical considerations limit how much the PWM duty cycle can step in the time of each period.  However, at one point in the rotation of the sensor, things will go from almost 100% back to almost 0% (or the other way, depending on the direction of rotation).

The tool lets you see what is going to happen for different PWM waveform steps, but it specifies one side of the step is 0%.  At most points, the step will be small, so looking at 0% to 1% is reasonable, but it‚Äôs also worth looking at 0% to 99%, for the case mentioned before, where things wrap around and the sensor goes from maximum duty cycle back to minimum.

For R and C values, you can select from this handy chart of common values.  What is happening here is that, over several PWM cycles of a given duty cycle percentage, the analog output voltage is filtered to be fairly constant and proportional to the duty cycle of the PWM signal.  If the RC value is too small, the analog value will jump around depending on just when it is sampled.  If it is too large, there will be a lag between when the PWM duty cycle changes and the analog voltage catches up.  Since the PWM changes will be limited by mechanical considerations, this is normally not a big deal ‚Äì except at the point where things wrap.

Also, if R is too small, it is possible to exceed the maximum current draw specification.  To check this, use Ohm‚Äôs Law: E = IR.  Here, 3.3V= 2mA (maximum) * R, or R (at a minimum) = 3.3V / 2mA = 1650Œ©.

The values I show above should be pretty reasonable.  There will be a small chance that you can read a value somewhere between 0% and 100% right around the point the sensor wraps around (which could be very incorrect), so it would be good to add a software check for this case.  Given that the software loop on the roboRIO runs at a slower rate, this can happen at most once per wrap ‚Äì but, in the worst case, the sensor could be sitting right at the boundary and bouncing back and forth, and so could be caught in transition more than once.  This scenario is highly improbable.  The issues around wrapping are really the main issue with using PWM as an input for this type of sensor.  Also using in the quadrature encoder (A/B) signals is probably the best option to manage this, but I suspect a lot of times, this is just ignored and things turn out OK.

Another thing is that the minimum and maximum analog voltages read will not be 0.0V and 3.3V.  So, the software needs to account for this as well.

Here‚Äôs the bottom line, assuming you want to connect a SRX MAG ENCODER to the roboRIO:

Connect 5V and GND to the roboRIO;

(Optionally but recommended) Connect A and B to DIO on the roboRIO;

Connect PWM to an analog input on the roboRIO, using the circuit above, with a 1.8kŒ© resistor and a 6.8ŒºF capacitor (this will likely have a +/- polarity, so pay attention to this);

Do the software thing ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know how much may be needed to use this sensor setup with any of the common swerve software, but pay attention to the issues outlined above.

EDIT: Crossed messages with @asid61 ; it looks to me as though either approach could work and I suspect both have been used.  The deciding factor could be someone else‚Äôs experience, how easy it is to handle the software side of things with one option as opposed to the other, or just try things both ways.

link_counts.title: (Sample)RC Low-pass Filter Design for PWM - Result -
Low-Pass Filter a PWM Signal into an Analog Voltage - Technical Articles

posts.name: Jacob Caporuscio
posts.cooked:
The SRX Mag Encoder does not have an analog signal.

Theoretically you can use additional hardware to convert the signal, but it‚Äôs unnecessary and requires additional technical know-how.

WPILib already has a class for getting the position from a PWM sensor, it‚Äôs DutyCycleEncoder.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Screenshot_20210212-073413_Chrome 1080√ó663 84 KB

Screenshot_20210212-073413_Chrome 1080√ó663 84 KB

Screenshot_20210212-073413_Chrome 1080√ó663 84 KB

Notice how the voltage goes up and down with the values you gave for R and C. This is called ripple voltage, and it‚Äôs at 0.27V here. The roborio could read the position anywhere inside that ripple. This means your effective encoder resolution just went from 12 bits to about 4, which isn‚Äôt precise enough to do much other than act as a volume knob on a car. Increasing that resolution is very difficult to do without a dedicated chip or vastly increased latency.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
I think DutyCycleEncoder is the right answer at this point.  I get filters and ripple.

However, the tool shows very different results for me ‚Äì the graph you posted shows both a lot of lag to a step transition and a lot of the PWM signal coming through.  Maybe the units are off somewhere?  Beside the point now, but I did run the numbers.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Ran it again, same result. Screenshot_20210212-075923_Chrome 1080√ó1856 152 KB

Screenshot_20210212-075923_Chrome 1080√ó1856 152 KB

Screenshot_20210212-075923_Chrome 1080√ó1856 152 KB

If you think of an RC Filter reducing the ripple by 20dB/decade, to filter a 244Hz signal by a factor of 100 (40dB), you would need a cutoff frequency of ~2.4Hz. That means a rise time on the order of hundreds of milliseconds, just to get a ripple that‚Äôs low enough to get a resolution of 100 positions per rotation.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
image 1172√ó980 38.6 KB

image 1172√ó980 38.6 KB

image 1172√ó980 38.6 KB

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: You have 99% duty cycle, which is close to ideal. 25-75% duty will give really bad ripple, with 50% being the worst case.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Yeah ‚Äì my bad, some rust here. If the tool allowed it, I most likely would have tried things on 1% to 99% and 49% to 51%.

FWIW, changing to a 22ŒºF gives results that I think could work, depending on the dynamics of the mechanical system, control loop frequency, etc.  This would work best when also using the quadrature encoder inputs (directly to the motor controller), so that the PWM would just be used to zero things initially (at that point, 47 or 100ŒºF would be fine, since the robot sits for many seconds powered up before it is enabled).

But I agree that using DutyCycleEncoder is clearly the most straightforward way to go here.

So, the original question is now about using this class with the swerve software.  I imagine someone else will have done this and can answer that part.  Sorry for the long detour ‚Äì hopefully, any interested readers will get something out of it.
